item.title: Golden-rule electron transfer rate with a nonequilibrium nuclear initial condition
Discretizing a continuum using the Gaussian-Legendre quadrature
item.description: A prototypical model for condensed-phase chemical reactions is the spin-boson model: a two-level spin coupled to a continuum of vibrations (bosons). The spin-boson Hamiltonian is \[ H = \sigma_x + \sigma_z \otimes \int_0^{x_\mathrm{max}} h(x) \rho(x)(a_{x}^\dagger + a_{x})\mathrm{d}x + \int_0^{x_\mathrm{max}} x\rho(x) a_{x}^\dagger a_{x} \mathrm{d}x \] Assuming $\rho(x)=1$, to discretize the continuum of bosons, we approximate the integral $\int_0^{x_\mathrm{max}} h(x) (a_{x}^\dagger + a_{x})\mathrm{d}x$ by \[ \sum_{n=1}^N \left\{ h(x_n) (a_{x_n}^\dagger + a_{x_n})W_n \right\} \]

item.title: The golden-rule electron transfer rate for a multi-state system
Quantum process tomography and the transfer tensor method for long-time non-Markovian dynamics
item.description: Motivation Predicting long-time dynamics from short-time information is a promising way of studying how equilibrium is approached for an open quantum system starting from a non-equilibrium initial condition. This post discusses one of the prediction methods for long-time open system dynamics, the transfer tensor method (TTM)1. The TTM is based on (i) the Nakajima-Zwanzig equation of an open quantum system [Eq. (1)], and (ii) the assumption that the state of the open system at a time $t$ is barely correlated with the state at $t'$ if $|t-t'|$ is greater than a certain threshold.

item.title: Lanczos tridiagonalization made simple
item.description: Given a real symmetric matrix $A$, one way to tridigonalize $A$ is the Lanczos procedure which I will introduce below. To transform $A$ into a tridiagonal matrix $T$, we need an orthogonal matrix $U$: $U^\dagger A U = T$ which implies $UT=AU$. Here, $$ T = \begin{pmatrix} \alpha_1 & \beta_2 & & & \\ \beta_2 & \alpha_2 & \beta_3 & & \\ & \ddots & \ddots & \ddots &\\ & & \beta_{N-1} & \alpha_{N-1} &\beta_{N}\\ & & & \beta_N &\alpha_{N}\\ \end{pmatrix}.

item.title: Thermo-field dynamics and mixed initial states
item.description: When simulating the dynamics of open quantum systems, one often assumes a pure initial state of the system part. The validity of the assumption, of course, depends on the experimental realization. In most of the excitation energy transfer experiments, a pure initial state is a faithful representation of the system because the coherent light that excites molecules makes the wave function of the system collapse to a certain state, hence factorizing the system-environment density matrix.

item.title: Jordan Wigner transformation made simple
item.description: The Jordan-Wigner transformation turns fermionic creation and annihilation operators into a combination of spin operators. I had a hard time understanding how it works until yesterday I came across the notes in this place. The notes list the definitions and the algebra of the “string+spin” operators. The notes themselves, however, still didn’t make me fully understand why things work like this. But fortunately, I worked out some Kronecker products (or tensor products) of spin operators when I was developing the fishbonett package.
